chunk_text: hypothesis is an idea or statement that explains observed facts and predicts new outcomes.
journal is a regular publication presenting articles on a particular subject.
peer review is evaluation of a personâ€™s work done by others in the same field.
immune reaction is a biological response involving the production of antibodies etc. as a reaction to the presence in the body of bacteria, a poison, or a transplanted organ.
topic: Dr Aklilu Lemma and the battle against bilharzia (schistosomiasis)

chunk_text: treated water is filtered or disinfected water made safe for consumption.
topic: Dr Aklilu Lemma and the battle against bilharzia (schistosomiasis)

chunk_text: genetic engineering is the deliberate, controlled manipulation of the genes in an organism, with the intent of making that organism better.
topic: Dr Aklilu Lemma and the battle against bilharzia (schistosomiasis)

chunk_text: microscope is an instrument for magnifying specimens.
light microscope is a microscope that uses a beam of light to form the image of an object.
electron microscope is a microscope that uses a beam of electrons to form an image.
magnification means increasing the size of an object.
resolution is the ability to distinguish between two separate points.
resolving power is how much detail the microscope is able to show.
stains are chemicals added to slide tissues to make the cells easier to see.
topic: Functions of different types of microscopes

chunk_text: wavelength is the distance between neighbouring wave crests.
cells are the basic structural and functional units in all living organisms.
cell theory states that cells are the basic units of life.
nutrition means food substances needed by the body.
respiration is the process whereby living organisms obtain energy from their food.
excretion is the removal of poisonous waste products produced by cells.
growth is the increase in size and mass of an organism.
irritability is the sensitivity of an organism to changes in surroundings.
movement is the need to get near to or away from things.
reproduction is the production of offspring to ensure the survival of a type of organism.
nucleus controls all cell activity and contains chromosomes.
topic: Structures and functions in unspecialised animal cells

chunk_text: cell membrane is the outer layer of living cell that controls the movement of substances in and out.
topic: Structures and functions in unspecialised animal cells

chunk_text: mitochondria carry out cellular respiration.
topic: Structures and functions in unspecialised animal cells

chunk_text: ribosomes are organelles involved in protein synthesis.
topic: Structures and functions in unspecialised animal cells

chunk_text: endoplasmic reticulum links the nucleus of a cell with the cell membrane.
topic: Structures and functions in unspecialised animal cells

chunk_text: cytoplasm is a liquid gel which contains all the organelles of a cell.
topic: Structures and functions in unspecialised animal cells

chunk_text: organelles are the small units inside a cell.
topic: Structures and functions in unspecialised animal cells

chunk_text: chromosome is a strand of DNA carrying genetic information.
topic: Structures and functions in unspecialised animal cells

chunk_text: enzyme is a protein molecule that acts as a catalyst in cells.
cell wall is the outer layer in plant cells and bacteria that is freely permeable.
topic: Structures and functions in unspecialised plant cells

chunk_text: cellulose is a complex carbohydrate that makes up plant cell walls.
topic: Structures and functions in unspecialised plant cells

chunk_text: vacuole is a fluid-filled cavity inside a cell.
topic: Structures and functions in unspecialised plant cells

chunk_text: specialised cells are adapted to carry out a particular bodily function.
undifferentiated cells are cells that have not yet assumed their final functional characteristics.
embryonic stem cells are cells from the early embryo that have the potential to form almost any other type of cell.
differentiated cells are special cells which carry out specific functions.
red blood cells are types of blood cell that carry oxygen around the body.
neurones are nerve cells.
genes are units of inheritance.
tissue is a group of cells that performs specific functions.
organ is a part of the body that carries out special functions.
epithelial cells are cells arranged in one or more layers to form part of a covering or lining of a body surface.
alveoli are microscopic air sacs in the lungs with a large surface area.
microvilli are minute hair-like structures that increase the surface area of a cell.
meiosis is cell division that reduces the chromosome numbers and forms the sex cells.
sperm is a male sex cell.
acrosome is a thin sac at the head of a sperm cell containing enzymes which dissolve the protective layers of an egg cell.
dendrites are short, arm-like protuberances of a nerve cell.
axon is an extension of a neuron that transmits messages.
muscle cells are elongated contractile cells that form muscle.
muscle fibres are strands of protein that enable muscles to contract.
diffusion is movement of particles from an area of high concentration to an area of low concentration along a concentration gradient.
osmosis is movement of water from an area of high concentration to an area of low concentration along a concentration gradient through a partially permeable membrane.
active transport is movement of substances against a concentration gradient using energy from respiration.
concentration is a way of measuring how many particles of a substance are in one place.
net means amount remaining after certain adjustments have been made.
concentration gradient is difference between an area of high concentration and an area of low concentration.
passive means uses no energy.
partially permeable means allows the passage of some substances but not all.
solvent is liquid in which a solute is dissolved.
solute is chemical that is dissolved in a solvent.
isotonic is solutions of equal solute concentration.
hypertonic is a solution with a greater solute concentration than another.
hypotonic is a solution with a lesser solute concentration than another.
dilute means to make less concentrated.
homeostasis is the maintenance of a constant internal environment.
turgor is when the cytoplasm of a plant cell is pushed hard against the cell wall by the vacuole which is filled with water.
flaccid means floppy, limp.
plasmolysis is when the cytoplasm of a plant cell shrinks away from the cell wall due to osmotic movement of water.
heterotrophs are organisms that feed on other organisms.
macronutrients are food you need in large amounts.
carbohydrates are a major food group made up of carbon, hydrogen and oxygen.
proteins are molecules made up of amino acids that are needed for the body to function properly.
minerals are inorganic compounds required by the body for good health.
vitamins are organic substances required by the body in order for it to function properly.
sucrose is a complex carbohydrate found in many plants and used as a sweetening agent.
glucose is sugar made by plants during photosynthesis.
photosynthesis is the process a plant uses to combine sunlight, water, and carbon dioxide to produce oxygen and sugar (energy).
starch is a nutrient carbohydrate required by the body for healthy functioning.
fructose is a sugar found in sweet fruits and honey.
condensation reaction is when two simple sugars combine to form a double sugar, removing a molecule of water.
complex sugars are when many single sugar units join to form a long chain.
glycogen is carbohydrate energy store found in animals.
cellulose is the main constituent in plant cell walls.
nitrogen is a colourless, tasteless, odourless, gaseous chemical element.
amino acid is a building block of protein.
peptide link is when amino acids are joined together in a condensation reaction and a molecule of water is lost.
pH is a measure of the acidity or alkalinity of a solution.
lipids are the general name for fats and oils.
cholesterol is a compound produced by the body; raised blood levels indicate a high risk of heart disease.
oils are a viscous liquid at room temperature.
glycerol is a syrupy, sweet liquid obtained from fats and oils.
saturated fat is with no double bonds in the structure.
unsaturated fat is with one or more double bonds in its structure.
single covalent bond is created when two atoms share a single electron.
double bonds are created when atoms share two electrons.
calcium(Ca) is an important constituent of bones and teeth, needed for many metabolic processes.
iron(Fe) is vital for making haemoglobin in red blood cells.
haemoglobin is a red pigment in the blood cells that carries oxygen around the body.
sodium is a vital element needed by the body for survival, by maintaining fluid levels.
deficiency disease is any disease caused by a lack of an essential nutrient.
night blindness is inability to see clearly in dim light due to vitamin A deficiency.
beri-beri is a deficiency disease from lack of vitamin B.
scurvy is a disease caused by lack of vitamin C in the diet.
retinol is vitamin A.
calciferol is vitamin D.
thiamine is vitamin B1.
urea is the main component of urine.
hydrolysis reaction is a chemical reaction of a compound with water.
nutrition is the obtaining of food in order to survive.
balanced diet is taking food from all major food groups in order to maintain a healthy body.
topic: Why is a balanced diet important?

chunk_text: undernutrition is too little food is eaten.
topic: Why is a balanced diet important?

chunk_text: overnutrition is too much food is eaten.
topic: Why is a balanced diet important?

chunk_text: malnutrition is diet is lacking in important elements needed for a healthy body.
topic: Why is a balanced diet important?

chunk_text: ingestion means taking in food.
mastication means chewing.
enamel is the top surface of teeth.
dentine is a living layer underneath tooth enamel.
pulp cavity is the centre of the tooth which contains nerves and blood vessels.
cement is a fibrous layer that holds the teeth into the jaw bone.
periodontal disease is a bacterial infection of the gums.
carbohydrase is an enzyme in saliva.
bolus is a saliva-coated chunk of chewed food.
reflex is an automatic reaction in the body that cannot be controlled.
oesophagus is the passage that food travels down from mouth to stomach.
peristalsis refers to wavelike muscle contractions to move food along.
sphincter is a ring of muscle.
stomach is a muscular bag that produces protease enzymes to digest protein.
pepsin is an enzyme that breaks down proteins.
hydrochloric acid is produced in the stomach to kill bacteria.
gall bladder is a muscular sac connected to the liver that stores bile.
bile is produced by the liver to aid in breakdown of food in the duodenum.
emulsify means breaking of large drops of fat into small droplets.
lipase is an enzyme that breaks down fats.
absorption is the process whereby the body absorbs food molecules.
villi are finger-like projections of the lining of the small intestine.
constipation is faeces that remain too long in the large intestine have too much water removed and become compacted and difficult to evacuate from the body.
diarrhoea is loose, watery faeces.
salmonella is bacteria that causes food poisoning.
carbon dioxide is a colourless, odourless gas formed during respiration and a widely produced greenhouse gas.
trachea is a major airway connecting the larynx with the lungs.
abdomen contains the digestive system and many body organs.
diaphragm is a muscle separating the chest cavity from the abdomen.
larynx is the voice box.
cartilage is a smooth rubbery material that reduces friction and cushions joints.
cilia are tiny moving hairs attached to cells.
bronchus is one of two main tubes branching off the windpipe.
bronchioles are small air tubes in the lung.
alveoli are tiny air sacs in a lung.
ventilation is moving air into and out of the lungs.
topic: How is air brought into your lungs?

chunk_text: intercostal muscles are muscles used in breathing.
topic: How is air brought into your lungs?

chunk_text: tidal volume is the amount of air breathed in.
vital capacity is the maximum amount of air that can be taken into the lungs.
weight is a measure of the heaviness of a person/object.
nicotine is an addictive drug found in tobacco smoke.
topic: The effect of smoking on the lungs and the rest of the body

chunk_text: carbon monoxide is a poisonous gas found in cigarette smoke.
topic: The effect of smoking on the lungs and the rest of the body

chunk_text: bronchitis is inflammation and infection of the bronchi.
chronic obstructive pulmonary diseases (COPD) means reduction of surface area of the lungs due to breakdown of the alveoli.
lung cancer is a disease linked to smoking.
aerobic respiration means using oxygen.
adenosine triphosphate (ATP) is the main energy storing molecule in a cell.
adenosine diphosphate (ADP) is an inorganic phosphate compound.
anabolism is reactions in the body which build up small chemicals into larger ones.
catabolism is reactions in the body that break down large chemicals into smaller ones.
metabolism is the sum of anabolism and catabolism in the body.
anaerobic respiration means breaking down food to release energy without oxygen.
lactic acid is a product of anaerobic respiration in animal cells.
oxygen debt is the amount of oxygen needed to break down lactic acid.
surface area to volume ratio is the amount of surface area per unit of volume.
blood circulation system is a system of blood vessels transporting blood around the body via the heart.
blood vessels are pipes throughout the body carrying blood.
heart is the pump inside the body that moves blood through the vessels.
blood is the medium which transports nutrients around the body.
double circulation means two transport systems within the body carrying blood from the heart to the lungs and back again; and all around the body and back again.
pulmonary circulation is when blood flows from the heart to the lungs and back again.
systemic circulation is when blood is pumped from the heart, all around the body and back again.
arteries carry blood away from the heart.
veins carry blood towards the heart.
capillaries link veins and arteries and take blood to all the organs and tissues of the body.
cardiac muscle is the muscle of the heart.
coronary arteries supply blood to the cardiac muscles.
atria are the top chambers of the heart.
ventricles are the large, lower chambers of the heart that pump blood out to the lungs and body.
valve is a mechanism in the veins that allows blood to flow in one direction only.
diastole is the relaxed heart when the blood pressure is lowest.
systole is the heart as it contracts, when the blood pressure is highest.
plasma is a pale yellow liquid component of blood that transports the blood cells.
red blood cells carry oxygen around the body.
haemoglobin is a red pigment inside red blood cells.
oxyhaemoglobin is a bright red product that forms in the blood when oxygen from the lungs combines with haemoglobin.
anaemia is a deficiency disease from lack of iron.
white blood cells form part of the bodyâ€™s defence against microbes.
phagocytes are white blood cells that engulf invading bacteria.
platelets are small components of blood that help it to clot at the site of a wound.
antigens are proteins found on the outer surface of all cells.
antibodies are proteins made by white blood cells that inactivate pathogens.
hypertension is high blood pressure.
topic: Two common problems of the circulatory system

chunk_text: bacteria are micro-organisms, members of the Monera.
flagella are parts of a bacterium that help it to move.
virus is a microscopic particle that causes disease.
moulds are fungi that are made up of minute, thread-like structures, producing fruiting bodies containing spores.
yeasts are single-celled fungi reproducing by asexual budding.
fungi are living organisms obtaining their food from dead or living organisms.
hyphae are thread-like structures of mould.
immune system is the system in the body which protects you against invading micro-organisms and foreign proteins.
antigens are proteins found on the outer surface of all cells.
immune is protected from the disease by the body having fought it off successfully previously.
sterilisation is the process of killing micro-organisms on an object by making it safe to handle without fear of contamination.
autoclaving is sterilisation of items in intense heat.
UHT is treating food with intense heat to kill micro-organisms.
pasteurisation is heating food to make it safe by killing most micro-organisms.
microbiology is the study of micro-organisms.
chemically means using antiseptics and disinfectants to kill micro-organisms.
topic: A chemical approach to controlling micro-organisms

chunk_text: disinfectants are chemicals applied to an inanimate object to kill micro-organisms.
topic: A chemical approach to controlling micro-organisms

chunk_text: antiseptic is a chemical applied to living tissue to kill micro-organisms.
topic: A chemical approach to controlling micro-organisms

chunk_text: agar is a substance which dissolves in hot water and sets to form a jelly.
crystal violet is a stain for colouring bacteria purple.
antibiotics are drugs which kill bacteria but do not harm human cells.
vaccination (immunisation) is the use of dead or weakened strains of pathogens to produce immunity to dangerous diseases.
parasites are organisms that live on or in another and take their nourishment from it.
tapeworm is a parasitic worm that lives in the intestines of humans.
cysticerci is a stage in the lifecycle of a tapeworm.
scolex is the knob-like anterior end of a tapeworm.
proglottids are segments of a tapeworm, each segment having male and female organs.
vector is something that transmits disease.
topic: The role of vectors in disease

chunk_text: malaria is an infectious disease carried by Anopheles mosquitoes.
topic: The role of vectors in disease

chunk_text: gastroenteritis is an intestinal infection causing acute watery diarrhoea.
cholera is an intestinal infection causing severe diarrhoea, vomiting and dehydration.
venereal diseases (VD) are sexually transmitted diseases.
sexually transmitted infections (STIs) are infectious diseases spread by sexual contact.
lymph is fluid containing white blood cells which flows through the lymphatic system.
lymphocytes are white blood cells forming antibodies against microbes.
T-cells are cells that recognise and attach to a cell carrying a foreign antigen and destroy it.
B-cells are cells that recognise and attach to a foreign antigen, reproducing and forming many identical copies of themselves which all secrete antibodies to destroy the foreign antigen.
species is a group of organisms that can breed successfully with one another to produce fertile offspring
pentadactyl means having five fingers or toes
morphology is the appearance of an organism
taxonomy is the process of classifying living organisms
taxa is a category in classification
binomial means having two names
dichotomous key is a type of key that is based on making successive choices between two statements or alternatives
prokaryotic cells are single-celled organisms without a separate nucleus.
eukaryotic cells are single-celled organisms with a nucleus.
dinoflagellates are microscopic single-celled organisms that cause bioluminescence in the sea when they produce a green light.
saprotrophs are organisms that feed off dead material.
mutualists are organisms that live in close association with each other and both benefit from this association.
mycorrhizae is an organic association between a fungus and the roots of a plant.
bryophyta is a plant division consisting of mosses and liverworts.
liverworts are small, green nonvascular plant growing in wet places.
mosses are nonvascular plants with a single stem and leaves of only one cell thickness.
pteridophyta is a plant division consisting of ferns.
ferns are plants of damp shady places.
gymnospermae is a plant division of conifers.
conifers are evergreen plants with needle-shaped leaves whose reproductive structures are found in cones.
angiospermae are true flowering plants.
rhizoids are simple root-like structures of mosses.
rhizome is a root which grows horizontally just below the surface of the soil.
spermatophytes are seed-bearing plants.
xylem is dead transport tissue in plants, moving water and minerals.
phloem is living transport tissue in plants that transports food around.
monocotyledons are any flowering plant having a single cotyledon (leaf) in the seeds.
dicotyledons are flowering plants with two embryonic seed leaves.
chaetae are bristle-like structures that help segmented worms to move.
tube feet are used by echinoderms to move around.
insecta means insects.
crustacea are aquatic creatures with bodies made up of a cephalothorax and abdomen, four pairs of legs, two pairs of antennae and simple eyes.
arachnida means spiders.
diplopoda means millipedes.
chilopoda means centipedes.
notochord is a flexible rod-like structure of cartilage running along the dorsal side of the body.
chordates are creatures characterised by a notochord, nerve chord and gill slits.
vertebrates are creatures with a vertebral column/backbone.
teleosts are bony fish.
elasmobranchs are cartilaginous fish.
amphibian is a creature who spends part of its life in water and part of it on land.
reptiles are cold-blooded, usually egg-laying, vertebrates.
wings are forelimbs of birds adapted for flying.
endothermic creatures are those who use heat produced by their own metabolism to regulate their body temperature.
mammals are creatures who produce milk for their young, have a high internal body temperature and regulate their own body temperature.
marsupials are mammals who produce immature young which are nourished by milk in the motherâ€™s pouch.
ecology is the science of the relationship between organisms and their environment.
ecosystem is all the animals and plants that live in an area along with the things that affect them.
environment is an organismâ€™s home and its surroundings.
habitat is a place where an animal or plant lives.
abiotic components are physical factors in a habitat.
biotic components are components linked to the plants and animals in a habitat.
terrestrial habitats are habitats on land.
aquatic habitats are habitats in water.
marine habitats are habitats in salt water oceans.
freshwater habitats are habitats in fresh water of lakes, rivers, ponds and streams.
camouflage is the ability of an animal to blend its colour into its surroundings to avoid detection.
phototrophs are organisms that feed off light.
producers are plants.
herbivores are animals that eat plants only.
carnivores are animals that feed on other animals only.
omnivores are animals whose diet includes both plants and animals.
heterotrophs are organisms that rely on eating other organisms.
chemotrophs are organisms that get energy from the breakdown of inorganic chemicals.
consumers are all of the animals that eat other animals or plants.
decomposers are bacteria and fungi that break down the remains of animals and plants, returning the nutrients to the soil.
trophic levels are levels in a food chain to which an organism belongs.
phytoplankton (plant plankton) are microscopic photosynthetic organisms at the beginning of many aquatic food chains.
zooplankton (animal plankton) are microscopic organisms which eat the phytoplankton.
food web is a network of food chains.
biomass is all the organic material produced by living organisms.
putrefying means decomposing.
nitrogen cycle is the cycling of nitrogen compounds between the living and non-living world.
legumes are plants with the ability to fix nitrogen in the soil.
denitrifying bacteria are bacteria that use nitrates as an energy source and breaks them down again into nitrogen gas.
carbon cycle is the cycling of carbon compounds between the living and the non-living world.
greenhouse effect is high levels of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere prevent heat radiating away from Earthâ€™s surface and causes the surface temperature to rise.
global warming is another term for greenhouse effect.
deforestation is the loss of forests due to the overcutting of trees.
adaptations are features organisms develop which make it possible for them to survive in particular habitats.
stomata are small openings in the leaves of plants.
succulents are plants which store water in their fleshy leaves, stems or roots.
